title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #760: Cochromatic Number of Subgraphs**

If G has chromatic number χ(G) = m, must G contain a subgraph H with ζ(H) ≫ m / log m?

**Status:** SOLVED (YES)

**Solution:** Alon-Krivelevich-Sudakov (1997)

The bound is tight - complete graphs achieve it.
mathContext: Connects chromatic number, cochromatic number, and Ramsey theory.

title: Independent Set
content:
**IsIndependentSet(G, S):**

A set S is independent if no two vertices in S are adjacent.

In a proper coloring, each color class is an independent set.

title: Clique
content:
**IsClique(G, S):**

A set S is a clique if every pair of distinct vertices in S is adjacent.

Cliques are the 'opposite' of independent sets.

title: Homogeneous Set
content:
**IsHomogeneous(G, S):**

A set is homogeneous if it's either a clique OR an independent set.

This is the key concept for cochromatic colorings - color classes must be homogeneous.

title: Chromatic Number
content:
**chromaticNumber(G):**

χ(G) = minimum number of colors for a proper coloring.

Each color class must be an independent set (no adjacent vertices share a color).

title: Cochromatic Number
content:
**cochromaticNumber(G):**

ζ(G) = minimum colors where each color class is homogeneous (clique or independent set).

**Key property:** ζ(G) ≤ χ(G) always, since independent sets are homogeneous.

title: Cochromatic ≤ Chromatic
content:
**cochromatic_le_chromatic:**

ζ(G) ≤ χ(G) for all graphs G.

Every proper coloring is also a cochromatic coloring (independent sets are homogeneous).

title: Complete Graph Bounds
content:
**Complete graphs show tightness:**

For Kₘ: χ(Kₘ) = m but ζ(Kₘ) = O(log m)

This means subgraphs H can only achieve ζ(H) ~ m / log m at best.

title: Erdős-Gimbel Theorem (1993)
content:
**erdos_gimbel_theorem:**

If χ(G) = m, then G has subgraph H with ζ(H) ≥ c · √(m / log m).

This was the first bound, weaker than the eventual solution.

title: Alon-Krivelevich-Sudakov Theorem (1997)
content:
**aks_theorem:**

If χ(G) = m, then G has subgraph H with ζ(H) ≥ c · m / log m.

**This solves Erdős Problem #760!**

The bound is optimal - complete graphs achieve it.

title: Problem Solved
content:
**erdos_760_solved:**

The answer to Erdős Problem #760 is YES.

Every graph with χ(G) = m contains a subgraph with ζ(H) ≫ m / log m.

title: Ramsey-Type Argument
content:
**ramsey_for_cochromatic:**

Any graph on n vertices has a homogeneous set of size ~ log n.

**Proof technique:**
1. Find homogeneous set S
2. Remove S and recurse
3. Build H from the decomposition

title: Clique Cover Number
content:
**cliqueCoverNumber(G):**

Minimum cliques needed to cover all vertices.

Equals χ(Gᶜ) - the chromatic number of the complement.

Relation: ζ(G) ≤ min(χ(G), cliqueCoverNumber(G))

title: Ramsey Number Connection
content:
**ramsey_number_bound:**

R(k,k) ≤ 4^k, so any n-vertex graph has homogeneous set of size log₄(n).

This logarithmic bound is why we lose a log factor in the main theorem.

title: Tightness of Bound
content:
**Why m / log m is optimal:**

1. Complete graphs: χ(Kₘ) = m, ζ(Kₘ) = O(log m)
2. Ramsey gives only log-sized homogeneous sets
3. Therefore ζ(H) can't exceed cm / log m

The AKS bound is the best possible!

title: Main Result Summary
content:
**erdos_760:**

**Status:** SOLVED

**Result:** ∃c > 0: χ(G) = m ⟹ G has subgraph H with ζ(H) ≥ cm / log m

**Timeline:**
- 1993: Erdős-Gimbel prove √(m / log m)
- 1997: AKS prove optimal m / log m

title: Historical Note
content:
**historical_note:**

The improvement from √(m / log m) to m / log m required new Ramsey-theoretic techniques.

This showcases how extremal graph theory benefits from combinatorial methods.

title: Open Direction
content:
**open_direction:**

What is the exact optimal constant c in ζ(H) ≥ cm / log m?

Current proofs give small constants; the best value remains unknown.
